entry.title: On patience and bus stops
entry.summary: Waiting at a bus stop can learn us something significant about human nature

div.p: Waiting is not for everyone. I'm good at it, though. Brilliant, if I may say so myself. I've practiced. I'm particularly good at waiting for public transports. Such as waiting for trains. Or buses.

Patience, states The Mirror (Saturday 19, 1825), is the art of waiting. That's true, for sure. But then editor continues: Time passes quickly with him who hopes for days and lives for the morrow. Hope has such efficacy that it can lead us to the end of life through an agreeable path and even beyond life itself. Interesting concept. Who would you like share an hour at a bus stop with: One who hopes or one that doesn't? In this case hope would imply the conviction that the bus will come and pick you up before you die, or at least so you arrive home before dinner.

I think that the The Mirror is wrong. Patience comes from the erroneous conviction that time spent waiting is an investment or an asset of some kind. The really patient person is the one who after waiting for (say) a quarter of an hour, dismisses the option to take a cab or walk, because he feels that he will then loose his investment in waiting. You've heard, haven't you: Let's wait five minutes more.
Mind you, the fallacy is aggravated by the fact that it takes just twenty minutes to walk to the station. Suppose it's better to start walking.
